snippet: Democrats and Republicans alike use legislative redistricting to keep and gain power, but it played especially well to Republican interests in this year’s elections.
abstract: Democrats and Republicans alike use legislative redistricting to keep and gain power, but it played especially well in this year's elections for Republicans, who were able to maintain control of House of Representatives even after losing popular vote; many see redistricting as one of the factors exacerbating political polarization (Series: Democracy Tested).

byline.original: By GRIFF PALMER and MICHAEL COOPER

lead_paragraph: Democrats and Republicans alike use legislative redistricting to keep and gain power, but it played especially well to Republican interests in this year’s elections.

headline.seo: Redistricting Helped Republicans Hold Onto Congress
headline.main: How Maps Helped Republicans Keep an Edge in the House
headline.print_headline: How Maps Helped Party Keep Edge In the House
